(Note that this was my first MAL review, hope you enjoyed)

Minami-ke isn't just another slice-of-life comedy that revolves around some main characters. Well, it does do that, but there is a mystical energy that comes from it that makes it not only funny, but pretty addictive to watch.
The whole story revolves around 3 sisters who have distinct personalities. There's Haruka, the eldest who is the most responsible of the three. She maintains the household, manages their bills, cooks the food and keeps everything in order in the house. There's Kana, the middle sister who has an energy that can't be beat. Although she's lazy and very gullible by her younger sister, she still shows hercreativity in some of her plans in the series. And finally there's Chiaki, the youngest who is the straight man who has the most negative attitude towards Kana and yet is kindest towards Haruka. Chiaki loves to mess with Kana as to misinterpret her love letters from a classmate of Kana's and keeps calling her dumbass. But it drives the story onwards.


Speaking of which, there practically isn't a story here. It is practically a Seinfeld of anime. There are many scenes in their home, scenes in their school and just daily observations and creative ideas that are bounced around in each episode. What makes it stand out is during some scenes, the attitude in the moment changes to a more serious attitude with a widescreen look and a more detailed view of each of the sister's faces. Funny at certain times, but can get kind of annoying at some moments. 


The content in this anime is pretty unique. Some of the episodes have them not doing anything and just hanging out around in their house where Kana and Chiaki are watching a funny soap opera titled "Sensei and Ninomiya-kun" where those words are all that they say. The elements of comedy in it are pretty original as well as some subjects could possibly be what bored girls could be talking about if they were to get together and talk about random stuff.


All in all, this was very enjoyable. I laughed a lot, quoted a lot of scenes with my friends and made me think a little at some points. Minami-ke has an addictive quality that made me impatient for the next episode. If you liked Azumanga Daioh and the like, you'll like Minami-ke.

I give this show an overall score of 5/10. I will recommend it to anyone who is bored and wants to relax to something moderate, lighthearted, and funny.
I laughed out loud a couple of times, and find myself smiling stupidly many times throughout the show. It is a silly, carefree, relaxing, and amusing sequence of both ordinary and odd moments shared between three very different sisters. So why the 5/10?
"Mediocre" is the best way to describe it.  It does not mean it is "bad". It just means that it is "average". This anime is not particularly special or even interesting. But I really enjoyedit (I rated it 8/10 in that regard), because I can certainly appreciate the mild nature of slice-of-life.


Story: 4/10, Decent

There is not really a "story" as much as there are "stories". I categorize slice-of-life shows into two sides: one with an objective, the other without. Minami-ke does not have an objective. It is merely comedy presented in a series of often unusual (but amusing nonetheless) situations shared between the three sisters and/or their classmates. The setting is basically exclusively limited to the Minami residence and their respective schools. There will be references that the show makes over the course of thirteen episodes (for example, the news broadcasted "loincloth festival" and television drama "Sensei to Ninomiya-kun" makes several appearances throughout the series) which can be rather comical if the audience watches every episode. Additionally, there is some character development throughout the show as well, such as the introduction of Chiaki's "younger brother" Touma, and her classmate Makoto's crossdressing schemes. 


Character: 6/10, Good

Speaking of character development, I have given it a score above "mediocre" because of the variation. Surely, an anime is not without its predictable, archetypal characters lined up, but Minami-ke is a little unique in its approach to the relationship between the Minami sisters and their classmates. The Minami sisters can be characterized as three siblings with jarring dissimilarities: Haruka is the eldest and the most mature and caring, Kana is the middle child with a hyperactive temperament and unrelenting stubbornness (and stupidity), and Chiaki is the youngest sister with principled self-assurance and somewhat monotonous  personality, although she has been shown to be very fond and appreciative of Haruka.  


However, it is because of this disparity that hilarity often ensues. Add even more contrasting and paradoxical characters from their schools and you have a wonderfully incompatible cast. 


Sound/Art: 7/10, Good

I give both sound and art a 7/10 because the two are consistent and conveys the action, emotion, and situational atmosphere very well. Considering the fact that this show is ten years old (well, very close to ten years old) at the time of writing this review, the art holds up incredibly well, and the sound (background music and voice acting) remains consistent and on-par with the art. The animation is not always fluid or even detailed, however, there is a slight nostalgic charm to it which may have likely not been the case had I watched this in 2007. 


Enjoyment: 8/10, Very Good

As mentioned, enjoyed this show very much. I finished it in two days. Yes, I was bored. Yes, I had "better" things to do. But I laughed quite a bit, and on a somewhat personal note, I have not been laughing very often lately. This really cheered me up, and I find all the characters rather likable. Nothing in this show bothered me, or made me frustrated enough to feel as if I should stop watching. Cheesy moments made their appearance every so often, but so did heartwarming ones. I really liked it.


Final verdict? 5/10. Do not think of this as "50%" It really just means that on a scale of absolutely-terrible-and-unworthy-of-viewing to amazingly-mind-blowing-and-revolutionary, it sits comfortably in the happy medium. And once again,  I recommend this.

Minami-ke is easily describable in American society, sitcom. Short for situational comedy, Minami-ke has no point or plot, but is simply the everyday antics of three sisters, Chiaki, Kana, and Haruka, who are in elementary, junior high, and high school respectively. A good point made by the writers is that they space out the ages of the sisters, so you see a lot of funny points made that one sister would know because they're older, but the other one or two don't. If you enjoyed this series, then you'll know quite well what episode included what weird things a boy and a girl do whenthey're alone.


Story:

Being what is commonly called a sitcom, there is no main plot. No one is trying to find their reason for existence or trying to romance another character. Although there is plenty of the latter, it isn't really significant to the story other than providing good comedy material. Other than that, all episodes have a main point, that is, they have one thing that its about, but it doesn't span the whole series. One episode they'll be talking about love and the next, food or celebration.


Art:

I watched the series as subbed by Ayako fansubs, and they tend to mess around a lot in their work. As such, in one episode, they mention that there is a use of Bible Black faces... although I know what they mean (characters will enter a state of "high-definition," lots of detail on the face (especially in the eyes) and plenty of shadow use to create a "dark" feeling), I don't exactly applaud their use of H-anime as a reference. Outside that, I've never seen the "teardrop mouth" used ever before, and it has been quite a while since I've ever seen an ahoge of that style. For reference, Chiaki has an ahoge, a little pouf of hair on her head, although more commonly today is the hair antennae. They're the same, but I haven't seen a lock of hair more than I've seen a strand or whatever you might call it. Other than that, the coloring is soft and "pastel-y," not really as detailed or mood colored as other anime, but since it's a comedy of three girls, the idea goes well. The characters all have a charm to them, perhaps due to the teardrop mouth.


Sound:

The music is fun in this series; and a little joy in the music reinforces the surroundings of the scene, and so works quite well. The OP and ED are also fun, it's more comedy centralized than the sequel.


Character:

The three sisters aren't too uncommon in culture today, although their combination in one family may be a bit unlikely. Chiaki is the quiet, young, conservative, intelligent, and rather harsh sister, who loves and helps Haruka but beats up on Kana. Her trademark name for Kana is repeated constantly throughout the series. Kana is the middle child, wild, lazy, carefree, unaware, and a bit demanding. She eats constantly, is always a bit dumb, and does nothing to help out the family. Whenever she does chores, it tends to make more work instead of finishing it. Her cooking is no exception... And to balance out the two, who always fight, there's Haruka. The older, wiser, and accomplished sister is always doing the work to support the two younger sisters, cooking, doing laundry, and paying the bills. She's a bit of a workaholic; without work she just lazes around, lethargic. She's also a bit carefree, as some may recognize as a bit of fanservice in the series. There's plenty more, with lots of other problems... but you'll have to see for yourself.


Enjoyment:

Random humor, well put and well timed helps the entire series. A series of pointless endeavors in life with funny situations and completely nonsense occurrences help reinforce that. It's as funny as they come, and being more modern, it feels like Azumanga Daioh!, a similar series with instead female students. Nonetheless, the pointlessness doesn't lose any of the cohesion in the series, so this is quite enjoyable to watch.


Overall:

Anime sitcoms are so much funnier than realistic sitcoms for one main reason. Reality sitcoms are limited by world limits. In the anime world, there is no possible end to the humor, so it is as funny as it gets. A short series with a sequel, this is fun to watch and fun to remember.

This anime just as the beginnng sequence says it is. It's about what happens in three ordinary sister's everyday lives. Don't expect too much.
Story: There isn't really much of a plot to this. It's about three sister that have very different personalities and what they go through in school, at home, with guys, things of that nature. It's the very definition of slice of life. You really shouldn't go into this anme expecting anything more than comedy. There's not much in the terms of drama, romance, or anything of that sort.
Art: The animation quality is by far not top notch. I mean, its not utterlyunbearable. The character designs match perfectly with their personality. The problem is that there's not enough detail in the backgrounds, but since it's just an anime for laughs, it doesn't really matter too much.


Sound: The opening and ending fit perfectly with the series. Very catchy and leading into what you are about to watch. The voices sound exatly like their personalities show it should. Kana's voice is very sarcastic and naive when it comes to tricks. Chiaka's voice is dead-panned just like the comments are suppose to be. And Haruka has the very sweet caring voice.


Character: The characters were quite unique. The sisters are all drastically different from one another, but so are the rest of the characters. Watching them interact is priceless. There's sweet ones, mean ones, brainless ones, perverted ones, love struck ones. They're all different, but they're all strange.


Enjoyment: I've never seen an anime like this. I thought a few of the scenes were just pointless, but they were suppose to be because it's jst s pointless its funny, but to me it's not. It's one of the best comedies I've seen. It's entertaining to watch how some simple misunderstandings turn into such outrageous things.


Overall, I think that if you enjoy comedy anime or anime with no real story to tell, you'll probably like this one.

Title: Minami-ke
Genre: Slice of Life, School Life, Comedy etc.
Story: 7
Although it is a light, comedy genre, which I personally like to watch, the story in itself does not seem to continue from the previous episodes even though there are some evident connections in "Ocean" episode. Critically just looking at the story line, I personally cannot give more than 7 because the storyline doesn't exist at all (I mean metaphorically)
Art: 10
The art to me is perfect, one of the styles that I like (pity for me when this changed in the second season). It's soft drawing fits well with the genre and the intention of theAnime, which consequently enhances the quality of the Anime as a whole.\n\n
Sound: 9\n
I have to admit that the sound is in fact exceptional, but in some cases it just doesn't seem to quite fit well with the atmosphere. Otherwise, the voice, BGM and the OP and ED fits well with Anime. Specifically talking of OP and ED, it is a enjoyable, fast and light music that goes quite well with characters and the "storyline".\n\n
Character: 10\n
The characters are perfect and the voice acting is just outstanding. The relationship between main and supporting characters adds up to the overall comedy and humour of the Anime, and the voice actors are really focused on the character and carries out their emotions effectively (especially Chiaki whose voices should be just like how Chihara-san has acted on my personal opinion). Good organization with the characters and their coherence is sound.\n\n
Enjoyment: 9\n
As one of the first Animes I have watched, it is a enjoyable Anime with bits of humours and comedy (although some are just for "Japanese-apt" people) and it gets you laugh and laugh all the way to the end, and you will realize that the Anime has actually finished too early. Some points are lost for the "Japanese only jokes"\n\n
Overall: 10\n
I would strongly recommend this Anime to anyone who is interested in Slice of life and when you get depressed and all that; watch this and you'll get over it. It is just full of joy and comedy that you can't miss out really. In my view, it is one of the masterpieces of small Anime-production company (It was horrible when the big guys took it over).

Minami-ke is a slice of life comedy, and stars the three sisters Haruka, Kana and Chiaki.
Story
Since this is a slice of life, it’s a bit obvious how the story goes. We see the daily lives of the sisters and their friends, with a different focus in each episode. Nothing special happens really. Still I really liked how the story was presented, and many characters were involved in various ways, and lead to a lot of hilarious moments. The writers (probably the mangaka as well) made great use of the huge amount of side-characters, without it feeling unnatural. That’s what I loved the most. Each episodewas unique, and about different persons each time. I also had trouble thinking what would happen next, in other words it was a very unpredictable show. And of course, and most importantly, it’s funny.


Art

Overall I’d say this show is very good looking. The colours used are great, and the show has a very soft feeling. Character designs are great too. The only thing I didn’t like, was that in some shots the characters’ noses looked a bit weird. They disappeared and it looked ridiculous. Thankfully it didn’t happen too often. Otherwise the animation is very consistent, and it maintains the calm atmosphere of the plot in a nice manner.


Sound

Good background music, quite good opening and ending, sound effects in place, and good voicing. What else is there to say?


Character

The three main characters, the sisters, are just great. They compliment each other in a really nice way, and they are hilarious. That aside, what I think is the best about this show, are all the supporting characters. There are so many, each of them unique, and they all get enough screen time to shine. The character designers must be geniuses (props to the mangaka as well, for making such great characters). The characters are the best thing about this show, in my opinion (I mean, Hosaka and Mako-chan are remarkable characters, they alone are almost enough to justify a 10 for characters!).


Enjoyment

Of course I enjoyed it, it was funny as hell. The episodes were all enjoyable, and I think I’m gonna rewatch this, as my first series. But still Minami-ke lacked something for me to give it top grade in this category.


Overall

All in all a very funny show, totally unpredictable and one of the better shows of 2007. Just go watch it.


Guess I’m gonna watch Okawari soon…

This is a comedy anime that is "kind of nonsense, but strangely interesting." It's a show similar to Lucky Star. Nothing much is to be expected from it, but it is definitely a MUST WATCH.
Before every episode starts, it is always stated not to expect too much from it. This show is simply about the Minami-ke sisters and their everyday lives. However, they are not your average, boring sisters so expect a lot of laughter from their thoughts, their actions, and their experiences.
This show is most creative with their art. The characters are drawn well and so is their environment. It's well animated. The onlyproblem they have here is that they have this really ugly face close-ups when a character is serious. Those specific close-ups destroy the overall beauty.


The sounds are great! Voices, SFX, music, OP, ED, everything is good.


Character is this show's highest point. The show is great because of their personalities and their very funny chemistry. They all fit in well. The only problem here is that there are times when the characters are too harsh or too weird that it's not funny anymore.


This show gives a high level of enjoyment since its great comedy will be making you laugh frequently. Everything is to be enjoyed from OP till the ED. However, with the stated problems, it doesn't give enjoyment to the max.

Sum it up in three words: Innovative, Cramps, Ninomiya-kun
This is going to be the first time that I will actually write a proper review, because I think this anime deserves one. Judging from its ranking, it is not so high, but I think this is one of the most under-rate anime today. There are so many people out there who tries to make funny anime, a lot of them are slapstick, and a lot of them are just so annoying because they try to be funny when they are not. (Hayate the Combat Butler for example) When an comedy anime is not funny, it isunforgivable. This doesn't apply to Minami-ke though.


Story: (No rating) This is not really an anime with a storyline, it is, as it says, the daily lives of three sisters. It is not something extra-ordinary, no espers and great big evil plots, it is EASY TO FOLLOW and laidback.


Art: At first I thought it wasn't very good, but as you get used to them, you will really start to like the style. I especially like how they draw the mouth, I think it is very cute! The people who wrote this anime also used DIFFERENT style of drawing at different situations, for example, when they are giving each other "evils" the art suddenly starts to become more mature and real, to make fun of the character's body language. tbh, there are a lot of original comedy that no one else has ever thought of, which is why I recommend it.


Sound: Well, the opening 


Character: In an anime that deals mainly in character-development, it does it outstandingly. At first sight, you will instantly fall in love with the contrasting personalities of the characters and you will "yearn" for how they interact. You will learn about new characters but the main focus is on the three sisters. It is ESPECIALLY good that one sister goes to primary school, another secondary and the third - high school. So there are things that the youngest sister don't understand such as she doesn't know what "doing naughty things" mean, while being teased by others. CLASSICAL. That is only to name one of many moments.


Enjoyment: “Sensei and Ninomiya-kun” <<< when you watch it, just look out for that. EVERY EPISODE, I LAUGHED OUT LOUD SO MANY TIMES. (In three years of watching Anime, I have NEVER laughed at an anime because it was funny, NEVER) Everything the characters do are very spontaneous but yet believable in a real life situation. Everything from cross-dressing to bikinis, you would never have guessed. IT NEVER CEASES TO AMAZE YOU.


Overall - I am not a person who really like comedy anime, I prefer the more deeper, emotional side of anime, so based on my reference, I can only give it a respectable 8. But if you love your comedy, you will definitely love this. (and if you don't prefer the comedy genre, this anime may give you a different outlook but be prepared to get cramps from laughing too much.

I am a pretty big fan of slice of life anime, but not indiscriminate. Minami-ke really grew on me after the first few episodes. My favorite thing about this series ( and the currently airing second season called Minami-ke Okawari) is the chemistry between the sisters ( especially Kana and Chiaki). In fact, these two have become some of my very favorite anime characters ever. Also, contains one of the cutest appearances by a stuffed animal I have ever seen ( Fujioka the Bear).
Of course, as with most slice of life, there is VERY little in regards to a plotline in Minami-ke. Most of theepisodes could probably be watched separately as stand alone comedies. The only "plots" that exist in the series is the story of Fujioka's affection for Kana, Makoto's and Touma's crossdressing, maybe a few other minor details that aren't coming to mind right now.


The characters and voice acting is what really gets me about Minami-ke. The characters are very lively, with their unique personalities, but aren't unrealistic in the way they behave. The artistic depiction of the characters is also more realistic than many other series ( not as many huge breasts flinging everywhere, or huge shapely hips, or unrealistic hair color, or girls that look underdeveloped/overdeveloped for their age). I think this "realism" is generally why I prefer Minami-ke to Lucky Star. Minami-ke still has a very high kawaii factor.


Overall, the series is funny, soft, not over-the-top, with great art/voice acting, and doesn't needlessly bombard you with pop-culture references ( if you enjoy these, I'd suggest Lucky Star).
